children.name: happen
children.definition: when sth happens, there is an event - used especially when talking about events that have not been planned
examples: When did the accident happen?
It’s impossible to predict what will happen next.

children.name: something/nothing/anything happens
examples: Something terrible has happened.
She carried on as if nothing had happened.
This wasbound to happensooner or later.
This kind of thinghappens all the time.
We’ll still be friends,whatever happens.

children.name: anything can/could/might happenused to say that it isuncertainwhat will happen
examples: You mustn’t go there alone at night. Anything might happen!

children.name: there be U
children.definition: there is/there areused when saying that a particular event happens :
examples: There was an earthquake about a week ago.
There are strikes almost every year.

children.name: occur
children.definition: formalto happen – used especially when talking about events (especially of accidents and other unexpected events) that have not been planned : xảy đến, xảy ra
examples: The incident occurred outside the police station at around 9 pm.
An accident involving over ten vehicles has occurred in the east-bound lane.
If any of these symptoms occur while you are taking the medicine, consult your doctor immediately.
A third of accidental deaths occur in the home.
The explosion occurred at 5.30 a.m.
RegisterIn everyday English, people usually sayhappenrather thanoccur:
The accidenthappenedwhile she was at school.

children.name: come about
children.definition: to happen, especially as a result of earlier events or decisions:xảy ra, xảy đến
examples: ▪ Our problems came about because we ignored the advice of experts.
▪ A number of educational reforms have come about as a result of the report.

children.name: come about through
examples: ▪ The decrease in the number of salmon has come about through commercial overfishing.

children.name: how did it come about that
examples: ▪ How did it come about that she married an awful man like that?

children.name: crop up
children.definition: informal to happen – used about problems or difficult situations, especially ones that are less serious, and can quickly be dealt with :xảyra, nổi lên bất ngờ
examples: The banks will contact their customers if a problem crops up.
A couple of problems cropped up while you were away.
If anything crops up, give me a call.
You have to learn to deal with difficult situations when they crop up.

children.name: come up
children.definition: to happen unexpectedly – used about problems, questions, or opportunities:xảy đến, nổi lên, nảy ra
examples: He rang to say he would be late home -- something had come up at the office.
There are job vacancies from time to time. I’ll let you know if anything comes up.
When the opportunity to go to the States came up, Dora took it at once.
There aren’t any jobs at the moment, but we’ll let you know ifsomething comes up.

children.name: turn up
children.definition: ifsthsuch as a job or a chance to dosthturns up, it happens or becomes available, especially through good luck:xảy ra, hiện ra
examples: Ben’s been looking for a job for two months, but nothing good’s turned up.
I’d almost given up hope of finding a house I liked, and then suddenly this one turned up.

children.name: strike
children.definition: to happen suddenly and unexpectedly – used about very bad events :ập đến
examples: It is always devastating when this illness strikes.
Most people were fast asleep when the hurricane struck at 4.05 pm.
The hurricane struck at around 1 am.
Disaster struck, and he lost all movement in his legs.

children.name: arise
children.definition: formalto happen unexpectedly – used about problems, arguments, or difficult situations :nổi lên, nảy sinh
examples: It would be best to deal with these issues at once, before a crisis arises.
A dispute arose about who should receive the money.
It is best to deal with the problem as soon as it arises.

children.name: arise over
examples: Several problems have arisen recently over questions of pay.

children.name: arise from as a result ofsth
examples: The conflict arose from tensions between the different ethnic groups.

children.name: to happen with a good or bad result
turn out
children.definition: to happen so that the final result is good, bad, unexpected etc:hóa ra, thành ra
examples: ▪ We were worried when only twenty people came to the party but it turned out very well.
▪ How did things turn out in the end?

children.name: turn out to besth
examples: ▪ I was a bit doubtful at first, but it turned out to be a really good idea.

children.name: not turn out as planned/expected
examples: ▪ We wanted the baby to be born at home, but it didn’t quite turn out as planned.

children.name: as it turned outused to say that this is what happened in the end
examples: ▪ As it turned out, James was delayed and didn’t arrive until three.

children.name: work out
children.definition: /pan out informal to happen with a particular result, especially a successful or unsuccessful one:kết cục, có kết quả
examples: Some election campaigns work out better than others.
We had a few problems when Jake first gave up work, but things are panning out very well now.
I’m not sure if we’ll decide to get married or not - we’ll wait and see how things work out.

children.name: go
children.definition: go well/badly/smoothly etcifsthsuch as an arranged event orsb’swork goes well, badly etc, it happens in a way that is successful, unsuccessful etc:trở nên, tiến triển, xảy ra
examples: Did the party go well?
Things went badly for the company last year. Their profits are down by 50%.
How’s the job going these days?

children.name: go off
children.definition: go off well/successfully/smoothlyetc if an arranged event goes off well, successfully etc, it happens and is completed without any problems: xảy ra, kết quả
examples: Thanks to the helpful staff at the hotel, the conference went off very well.
I’m sure that everything will go off smoothly on the day.

children.name: go off without a hitch happenwithout any problems
examples: Everyone was relieved when the ceremony at the Ambassador’s residence went off without a hitch.

children.name: ways of saying that sth is happening
be happening
children.definition: /biː ˈhæpənɪŋ/

children.name: be going on
children.definition: if sth is going on it is happening, especially if it makes you feel worried or annoyed: đang xảy ra
examples: It was obvious from the way they kept looking at each other that there was something going on.
what’s going on?

children.name: ▪ ‘What’s going on at the town hall?’ asked my mother. ‘There’s a huge crowd of people there.’
in progress
children.definition: be /biː ɪn ˈprəʊgresǁ-ˈprɑː-/  formal if an arranged event, game, or operation is in progress, it has started and has not finished yet: đang diễn ra
examples: ▪ By the time we got to the stadium, the match was already in progress.
▪ There must be no noise in the school while examinations are in progress.
▪ An emergency relief operation is already in progress in Southern Sudan.

children.name: on
children.definition: be  to be happening now or to be going to happen:
examples: The summer sales are on next week.
People have to learn to economize when there is a war on.
The presidential election was on when we arrived in the States.

children.name: be in full swing
children.definition: if an organized activity or an event such as a party is in full swing, it has already been happening for some time and people are taking part in a very active way: đang diễn ra sôi nổi
examples: ▪ By 10 o'clock the party was in full swing and everyone was dancing.
▪ Barcelona was full of visitors, and preparations for the Olympic Games were in full swing.

children.name: when what you want or expect happens
come true
children.definition: if yourwishes,dreamsetc come true, what you have wished for or dreamed about actually happens:trở thành hiện thực
examples: Patterson’s dream came true when he won the Boston marathon on his first attempt.
People say that if you make a wish at the top of the hill, it always comes true.

children.name: be realized
children.definition: alsobe realisedBritish /biː ˈrɪəlaɪzd/  if your expectations, hopes, fears etc are realized, what you expected or hoped for actually happens:
examples: ▪ At thirty-five her ambition of running her own business was finally realized.
▪ My worst fears were realised when I saw what was on the exam paper.

children.name: be fulfilled
children.definition: /biː fʊlˈfɪld/  if a wish or promise is fulfilled, what someone wished for or was promised actually happens:
examples: ▪ Tom decided to run the farm himself, so that his father’s wish might be fulfilled.
▪ We knew that the ‘democratic elections’ were a promise which would not be fulfilled.

children.name: materialize
children.definition: alsomaterialiseUK if an event which has been planned, expected, or promised materializes, it actually happens:được thực hiện
examples: Even if the salary rise materialises, it won’t be worth much.
It was rumoured that Apple would be sold to Sun Microsystems, but that deal never materialized.

children.name: fail to materializenot happen
examples: The promised recovery failed to materialize and unemployment kept on rising.

children.name: happen
children.definition: xảy ra
examples: We’d always feared that this might happen.
For some time there had been predictions of a major earthquake, and then on April 19, 1906, it happened.
I want to make things up with her, but I don’t think it’s going to happen.

children.name: happen again
children.definition: xảy ra lần nữa
examples: ▪ She apologized for the incident and promised it wouldn’t happen again.
▪ I think I’ve solved the problem with your computer, but let me know if it happens again.

children.name: recur
children.definition: formal to happen again, once or repeatedly: tái diễn
examples: Although the treatment for skin cancer is usually successful, the problem can recur later.
Some people find that the same dream keeps recurring over a period of many years.

children.name: repeat performance
children.definition: sththat happens in exactly the same way as it happened before, usually with all the same problems: sự tái diễn
examples: The journey to work had taken hours that morning, and I wasn’t looking forward to a repeat performance on the way home.

children.name: repeat performance of
examples: We must try to make this summer camp a success. We don’t want a repeat performance of last year’s disaster.

children.name: repeat itself
children.definition: use this to say that things happen again in just the same way:lặp lại
examples: Stricter controls of farming methods are needed, if we want to prevent the disaster from repeating itself.
history repeats itself
The Cambodian people were afraid that history would repeat itself.
repetition/repeat [C] an event or action that is the same as sth that happened before: sự tái diễn
repetition/repeat of
Hopefully, the experience will help us to avoid a repetition of our mistakes.
A lot of the lesson was just a repetition of what we’d already done.
Will next Saturday’s game be a repeat of Germany’s triumph last season?

children.name: take place
children.definition: to happen - use this about events, performances, ceremonies and other things that have been planned to happen: diễn ra
examples: The wedding will take place at St Andrew’s church.
Police are trying to prevent the demonstration from taking place.
The conference will take place on the 16th of June.
The competition took place on Saturday 30th June.

children.name: be coming up
children.definition: if a planned event is coming up, it will happen soon:sắp diễn ra
examples: Don’t forget you’ve got exams coming up in a couple of weeks’ time.
Our 12th annual Folk Festival is coming up again soon.

children.name: be
children.definition: if a planned event is at a particular time or place, it happens or is arranged to happen at that time or place: xảy ra, diễn ra
examples: Dinner is at eight, so come at about half past seven.
Christmas will be on a Saturday next year.
Last year’s degree ceremony was in the main university building.

children.name: get underway
children.definition: to begin
examples: The film festival gets underway on 11th July.

children.name: present itself
children.definition: If something presents itself, it happens
examples: Anopportunitysuddenly presented itself.

children.name: in the event of sth
children.definition: in the event ofsth

children.name: if something happens
examples: In the event of a strike, the army will take over responsibility for firefighting.

children.name: up
children.definition: adverbPROBLEM

children.name: underway
children.definition: ,under wayadjective

children.name: 1. If something is underway, it is happening now
examples: Economic recovery isalreadyunderway.

children.name: return
children.definition: if a feeling, situation etc returns, it starts to exist or happen againSYN come back:
examples: If the pain returns, take two of the tablets with some water.
David could feel his anger returning.
You must go to the doctor if the pain returns.
return to
when peace finally returns to this country
RegisterIn everyday English, people usually say that a feelingcomes backrather thanreturns:
I’m worried that the pain willcome back.

children.name: rage
children.definition: verb

children.name: 2. to happen in a strong or violent way
examples: The storm raged outside.
A flu epidemic is raging in/through local schools.
The argument rageson(= continues strongly) .

children.name: have
children.definition: verbhad,had CAUSE

children.name: follow
children.definition: verbHAPPEN

children.name: follow
children.definition: verbBE RESULT

children.name: fall
children.definition: verbfell,fallenHAPPEN

children.name: come
children.definition: verbcame,comeHAPPEN

children.name: become of sb/sth
children.definition: become ofsb/sthphrasal verb

children.name: If you ask what became of someone or something, you want to know where they are and what happened to them
examples: Whatever became of that parcel you sent?
And Mickey Adams - I wonder what became of him.
